ygData.subject: Re: Finding a University to do a PhD in Evolutionary & Adaptive Networks
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Ken, Thanks so much for your suggestions. And, yeah, it was adaptive neural networks that I was referring to :) Cheers, Mike

Hi Ken,

Thanks so much for your suggestions. And, yeah, it was adaptive ne=
ural
networks that I was referring to :)

Cheers,
Mike

--- In neat@yahoogr=
oups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Mike,
> 
> I'd guess =
there are others in the group with similar questions so I
> think it's prob=
ably useful to the group. (By the way, by "Adaptive
> Networks," I assume y=
ou are referring to adaptive neural networks?)
> 
> In any case, another op=
tion is the University of Texas at Austin,
> which is where I did my Ph.D. =
under Prof. Risto Miikkulainen, who has
> a leading group in the area:
> 
>=
 http://nn.cs.utexas.edu
> 
> Another good lab is Prof. Jordan Pollack's DE=
MO Lab at Brandeis:
> 
> http://www.demo.cs.brandeis.edu/
> http://www.cs.b=
randeis.edu/~pollack/
> 
> However, Jordan tells me that he will be renamin=
g and revamping his
> lab soon, so it will no longer be called "DEMO."  How=
ever, it is
> undoubtedly still a good place to be.
> 
> There are some new=
er places too with groups led by new professors,
> including Prof. Bobby Br=
yant's "Neuroevolution and Behavior
> Laboratory" at the University of Neva=
da at Reno
> (http://nebl.cse.unr.edu/) and Prof. Josh Bongard's new group =
at the
> University of Vermont (http://www.cs.uvm.edu/~jbongard/).
> 
> Pro=
f. Hod Lipson at Cornell formerly worked with Prof. Pollack and
> runs the =
Cornell Computational Synthesis Lab:
> 
> http://ccsl.mae.cornell.edu/
> 
>=
 However, that lab is a focused on emergent phenomena in general, with
> a =
broader scope than some of the others.
> 
> One other important group is Pr=
of. Dario Floreano's Laboratory of
> Intelligent Systems.  This lab is in S=
witzerland, so I am not sure if
> it conducts its day-to-day work in Englis=
h (it might), but in any case
> it is very prominent in the area:
> 
> http=
://lis.epfl.ch/
> 
> Not all these groups have an explicit focus on neural =
networks, but
> most have done some good work with them.
> 
> Note that any=
 Ph.D. program in North America should be willing to
> support you financia=
lly if you get in.  
> 
> ken
>  
> 
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "=
frayn.michael" <frayn.michael@> wrote:
> >
> > Hello everyone,
> > 
> > I a=
m about to head over to the University of Sussex (in Brighton,
> > England)=
 to do their MSc in Evolutionary & Adaptive Systems.
> > 
> > However, as I=
 am Canadian, the concept of doing a PhD there is a
> > little daunting bec=
ause of the cost. Unfortunately, I am not aware of
> > many other Universit=
ies that would be interested in funding a PhD of
> > such research focuses =
(let alone would be able to comprehensively
> > support students along the =
way). This assumes, of course, that my MSc
> > is wildly successful and I c=
ome up with a research question worthy of
> > funding.
> > 
> > Anyhow, I w=
as hoping that some of the members here might be able to
> > point out othe=
r Universities (in North America or English-speaking
> > Europe) that may b=
e appropriate to do such a PhD in. These are the
> > ones I'm familiar with=
 now:
> > 
> > University of Edinburgh
> > University of Sussex
> > Univers=
ity of Central Florida
> > 
> > I realize this isn't directly related to NE=
AT but I couldn't think of
> > a more knowledgeable group on the subject ma=
tter a hand. If there is a
> > more appropriate group, then please just poi=
nt me in the right
> > direction and I'll not post about this again here. A=
pologies if it's
> > too off-topic.
> > 
> > Cheers,
> > Mike
> >
